‎06-07-2012 10:48 AM

suzew1 wrote:

 

I just thought the Bernard regiman sounded a bit extreme.


I agree. Especially when you really cut back on the so called "healthy whole grains" that really aren't very healthy for a diabetic in anything more than minor quantities, then cut back the rest of the so called "healthy" and starchy veggies and the fruit sugar laden fruit to portions that don't spike BG. Leaves one with a rather small selection left to choose from. So while I do enjoy non starchy veggies like broccoli, eggplant, etc., I also find adding some meat and cheese goes a long way into a sustainable and healthy diet. Also, just looking at how diabetes can be traced in my own family history to predate all the modern processed foods that currently get blamed, I'm confident the only way I could have prevented those diabetes genes from catching up to me would have been to die by the time I hit 40, or never been born at all. So I'll take the diabetes and eat to my meter...it tells me I can have a nice mix of foods, just like an omnivore is designed for

Re: Dr Neal Barnard

‎06-07-2012 08:24 PM

As a former TV investigative reporter for 18 years, and a current author who gets invited to speak all over, I have many Google alerts that I read daily. When I see blatant misinformation, as I did with the post I responded to, I just like to add my two cents. Take it or leave it. No one pays me. I just try to help others improve their health relatively easily, not counting calories and following what has worked for so many others. When you've watched your sisters go through wretched breast cancer multiple times, see your relatives lose limbs to diabetes and then followed by hearts getting cracked open for heart disease, you get pretty incensed when you see how a low-fat, plant-based diet can reverse it so relatively easily. Oh yeah, my best friend died of breast cancer too. On her death bed as the chemo ate her alive, she said, "Take care of my kids." She had a great hubby who did that. But speaking out when I can, is how I honor her request. She tried to change her diet the last months of her life. It was too little, too late. 

 

I also just watched the HBO 4-part series, Weight of the Nation, which if you have seen, is another huge reminder that preventable disease is not sustainable. And...that there is so much needless suffering that can easily be prevented. Maybe not for everyone, but for many. Worth a try before bariatric surgery...but maybe that's just me. The series points out how many kids are getting diabetes and heart disease in early childhood. That is not right.

 

Since I've done Atkins, South Beach and every other diet under the sun trying to keep my girlish figure for TV and personal health, and now as a personal trainer and running coach, the "truth" seems pretty obvious to me. There's no money in broccoli. It really is that simple.

‎06-07-2012 09:16 PM

Topic started 07-06-2012 12:36 AM (My time): Dr Neal Barnard

 

I wrote: 07-06-2012 10:18 AM

His devotees are totally committed but rarely stay here more than a week or two. You can expect a few to appear in this topic shortly because they use bots to watch for a mention of Barnard.
EllenJaffeJones appeared: 08-06-2012 12:22 AM
Spoiler
EllenJaffeJones wrote:

I'm an AFAA certified personal trainer, RRCA running coach, and volunteer high school running coach. I was a TV investigative/consumer reporter for 18 years in St. Louis/Miami and won the highest awards in broadcasting including 2 Emmys. More importantly, my mom, aunt & both sisters had breast cancer. One of those sisters, both parents, all grandparents: diabetes & major heart disease. Mom, grandmother, uncle: Alzheimer's. Most women had/have osteoporosis, and everyone had arthritis and major colon problems/disease. I've been searching for answers since my aunt died of breast cancer in our home when I was 5. That is my only "agenda."

 

I almost died of a colon blockage at 28 and began a vegan diet which I have maintained for most of the past 31 years. I now place in 5K races for my age group, did my first marathon at 58 & was the 5th oldest female to finish the Palm Beaches Marathon. I run faster and longer now than I did at 28. My 100 meter sprint times are close to the NCAA times for the USC girls track team. At almost 60, the media has written about my ability to beat the odds.

 

Google Center for Consumer Freedom and Rick Berman, and you'll see "60 Minutes" and others who have tried to expose him for his work defending tobacco, firearms and fast food. As a reporter, I followed the money, and when you understand there's no money in broccoli, then you understand why you have to be your own investigative reporter. My cholesterol went from 135 to 203 in one year when I went from a vegan diet to Atkins (I thought the science had changed...only the marketing had, I learned later). It went right back down when I returned to vegan diet.

 

Barnard was one of the first doctors to write about a healthy plant-based diet reversing diabetes and heart disease.

Spoiler

His work and that of many other plant-based docs have courageously helped Clinton and other CEOs who have figured out that this is much more convenient/cheaper than having your chest cracked open or taking insulin forever. His work has saved my life!

 

I began teaching cooking classes and saw student's A1C numbers come down, and one woman lost 120 pounds in 8 months without counting a single calorie and loving the food. She had been given up for dead with multiple myeloma, and almost a decade later, she is still alive, blood work great, and a joyous vegan. Our local newspaper did a story on her (it's on my "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day" Facebook page) because her before and after pix were so dramatic. And yeah, I used my financial background to write the book after I saw too many stories of 300 pound women loading their carts with Twinkies saying, "You can't eat well on a budget." Nonsense...beans are way cheaper/healthier than meat/dairy. Not to mention how much money you save by avoiding doctors, disease and hospitals. I've crunched all those numbers.

 

Eating whole foods in their natural state (healthy carbs, whole grains, lots of veggies) is the best kept secret in America! Why? Because there's no money in broccoli! There's no board, lobbyists or association. Do your homework on this, and you'll see the numbers and where the money goes. Ask any of your docs how many nutrition classes they took in med school. It's usually zero. Ask them how many junkets they went on sponsored by pharma, or who paid for new wings of their hospital. Ask who paid for the research they worked on. Then ask your doc if veggies are right for you. Oh yeah, a whole-grain, balanced plant-based diet can reverse ED too! All arteries and organs are connected. Connect the dots. These are diseases of affluence and they don't exist in countries that have access to our processed, high-fat, hormone-laden foods. 

 

My sis who had heart disease and diabetes...she was overweight and had "routine" herniated disc surgery during which, she flatlined while contracting MRSA through the IV. She's now a quadriplegic and got breast cancer within the year of the surgery. My dad lost his eyesight and limbs to diabetes...so common in this mostly preventable disease. Eating a plant-based diet as described by Barnard, is way easier than all that. I only say this because no one should endure the pain/suffering I've experienced and seen. Not in this country. Not anywhere. So what if a few animals are saved from the awful factory farming atrocities that well-documented now all over YouTube? That's why many kids are going vegan...they don't want to stick their heads in the sand and pretend they don't see. But it's also humans who can be helped as much too. I see this up close and very personal. I wish I had time to wait for more studies, but I don't have time.

 

Preventable diseases are not sustainable, and if we don't get this under control, our country is doomed. It will be a game of survival of the fittest. I keep begging to be studied...you'd think researchers would be lined up at my door. Every study I've looked at in the last 6 years requires you to have cancer or be willing to take a drug. Imagine that?! Barnard's way of eating (and Drs. McDougall, Furhrman, Essystyn, Campbell etc.) does work. Look at Clinton, and the growing numbers of folks who are figuring out that their doctor may not have the necessary education to figure this out. While people can be different, some of these concepts do work well for many or most people. Good luck on your journey!

 

 

Nearly 24 hours. What took you so long?

 

You need a better search bot.

 

I'm not going to bother asking whether you have diabetes. I know you don't.

Cheers, Alan, Type 2, d&e metformin 2000mg, Australia.
Everything in Moderation - Except Laughter.
There is nothing I could eat I like more than my eyes.
Type 2 Diabetes - A Personal Journey(latest: Fat: The New Health Paradigm)
Born Under a Wandering Star (Latest: Ella to Kandy, Sri Lanka)

‎06-07-2012 09:21 PM


EllenJaffeJones wrote:

As a former TV investigative reporter for 18 years, and a current author who gets invited to speak all over, I have many Google alerts that I read daily. When I see blatant misinformation, as I did with the post I responded to, I just like to add my two cents. Take it or leave it. No one pays me.

Spoiler

I just try to help others improve their health relatively easily, not counting calories and following what has worked for so many others. When you've watched your sisters go through wretched breast cancer multiple times, see your relatives lose limbs to diabetes and then followed by hearts getting cracked open for heart disease, you get pretty incensed when you see how a low-fat, plant-based diet can reverse it so relatively easily. Oh yeah, my best friend died of breast cancer too. On her death bed as the chemo ate her alive, she said, "Take care of my kids." She had a great hubby who did that. But speaking out when I can, is how I honor her request. She tried to change her diet the last months of her life. It was too little, too late. 

 

I also just watched the HBO 4-part series, Weight of the Nation, which if you have seen, is another huge reminder that preventable disease is not sustainable. And...that there is so much needless suffering that can easily be prevented. Maybe not for everyone, but for many. Worth a try before bariatric surgery...but maybe that's just me. The series points out how many kids are getting diabetes and heart disease in early childhood. That is not right.

No-one pays you?

 

At 59, Ellen Jaffe Jones is "THE VEG COACH." AKA "The Broccoli Rep." Because as she says, "Who else IS the broccoli rep?" She is an inspiring motivational speaker, personal trainer, running coach, author, and teaches healthy cooking classes designed by respected doctors and registered dieticians.

Ellen's best-selling book, "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day" rapidly became her publisher's #1 seller. Ellen's publisher credits part of the success with Ellen's dedication to and use of social media saying, "Her success with social media has been amazing!" Ellen now coaches other authors on how to build their social media "presence." As a result of this success, her publisher requested that she write another book, which will be out later this year or early 2013.

 

As an author and motivational speaker on the subject of Veganism I suspect you are paid rather well for advocating this way of eating.

Cheers, Alan, Type 2, d&e metformin 2000mg, Australia.

Am I the only one that is utterly tired of the continous HARASSMENT by these vegans? They're incredibly lucky that the internet is some sort of a no man's land, as there's very little legal recourse against behaviors like theirs that in real life could be punishable by law. Also, I can't believe that these people have animals as their #1 priority over humans and don't have any scruples in HARASSING the community of the ADA forums (which is made up of people suffering from this terrible disease called diabetes) for their pro-animal agenda.

 

I just hope that Matt and the other admins will deal very swiftly with this continous propaganda, because in all honesty, the more I see of this, the less I want to participate in any discussion/topic in the forums. This vegan offensive that has been constantly going on for months, really disgusts me.

 

 

Name: Al
Location: Massachusetts South Shore

‎06-07-2012 11:06 PM - edited ‎06-07-2012 11:07 PM

That is correct, I do not get paid for any of my appearances. I'll be lucky if I make enough money a few years from now to cover the cost of bringing my website up to current 21st century standards and buying a laptop suitable for travel.

 

If you know anything about the struggling book publishing business, you would know that unless you publish many successful books or write the great Amercian novel, there's tragically little money to be made as an author.

 

My publisher asks me to go speak a few times a month on weekends and pays my airfare and lodging at cheap motels. I know authors who blew their entire 50K advance hiring a publicist to try and get on Ellen. Most authors I know, like me, have successful "day" jobs that allow them to take the time, energy and personal money it takes to write a book. 

 

My financial goal is simply not to lose money on the whole thing. I didn't get paid any advance. This has been a total labor of love, and despite the intense hostility here, which I have no patience for, I take great satisfaction knowing I've helped a lot of people too. 

 

As I said, I'm doing this to try to get the word out about what has worked for me and so many people. My parents were so sick and diseased with heart disease and diabetes, that by the time I had kids, they couldn't lift them, let alone babysit them. Many news stories talk about the current generation may be the first to not outlive the generation before them. Like Bill Clinton who said as he went vegan, I want to be around for my grandkids.

 

If you've checked me out as you say you have, you'll know that I have written that I am the only healthy person in my family of origin, by a long shot. That means I have no diseases. I'm not trying to hide that. To the contrary. I have been diagnosed as hypoglycemic since I was a child (too many flavors of Baskin Robbins), and have worked hard my adult life making sure that didn't erupt into the diabetes everyone else in my family had/has.

 

Based on the similar writing styles, I suspect there are some paid flacks writing here as there elsewhere. Or maybe some people hide anonymously to say ugly things. I don't know and don't care. Of course people like me would spend little time here. Why bother or waste more time? I've said my peace and choose to spend my time in stressfree ways to avoid disease. I don't wish to engage in your personal attacks. I'm happy to share my knowledge, resources and information with anyone who is genuinely interested in learning, but not in a community that seems to have no interest and enjoys dissing with one-sentence attacks. 

 

If you find me on Facebook, you'll see all the races I've place in...plant-powered, pushing 60. The media have written about my ability to defy the odds of my huge family history of cancer, heart disease and diabetes. Those who are interested will continue the journey. Blood tests don't lie. Whatever works for you. Good luck to you all. 

 

And no worries, I have all the business I can handle with personal training clients. Regardless of diet, there's quite a demand for 60 year-old personal trainers who can outrun most college/high school kids. Must be doing something right, they think.
